Council 1

Minakshi Menon

Minakshi Menon's Website

@menon_minakshi

Current Position

Research Scholar, Max Planck Institute for the History of Science, Berlin

HSS and Related Activities

  • Co-Chair, Forum for the History of Science in Asia, 2016 --
  • Editorial Advisory Committee, HSS Newsletter, 2019 --
  • Contributor, "Eighteenth-Century Scotland", Newsletter of the Eighteenth-Century Scottish Studies Society

Publications

  1. Menon, Minakshi. “Transferrable Surveys: Natural History from the Hebrides to South India.” Journal of Scottish Historical Studies 38, no. 1 (May 2018): 143-159. 10.3366//jshs.2018.0238.
  2. Menon, Minakshi. “Grains of Paradise and Reading against the Grain: Telling Stories about Science in the Global South.” Studies in History and Philosophy of Biological and Biomedical Science 66, no. 003 (September 2017): 82-86. doing.org/10.1016/j.shpsc.2017.09.003.
  3. Menon, Minakshi. “Medicine, Money and the Making of the East India Company State: William Roxburgh in Madras, c. 1790.” In Histories of Medicine and Healing in the Indian Ocean World, edited by Anna Winterbottom and Facil Tesfaye, 151-178. New York: Palgrave MacMillan, 2015.
Council 2

Projit Mukharji

Projit Mukharji's Website

Current Position

Associate Professor, History & Sociology of Science

HSS and Related Activities

  • Book Review Editor, Isis, 2019 - present
  • Member, Committee on Meetings and Programs, 2018-present
  • Member, Essay Prize Committee, Forum for the History of Science in Asia (FHSAsia), 2014
  • Founding Member, Forum for History of Science in Asia (FHSAsia)
  • I have attended most HSS meetings since 2011
  • Editorial Board, History of Science, 2020 - present.

Publications

  1. Mukharji, Projit. Doctoring Traditions: Ayurveda, Small Technologies and Braided Sciences. Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 2016.
  2. Mukharji, Projit. Nationalizing the Body: The Medical Market, Print and Daktari Medicine. London: Anthem Press, 2009.
  3. Mukharji, Projit. “Handwriting Analysis as a Dynamic Artisanal Science: The Hardless Detective Dynasty and the Forensic Cultures of the British Raj.” In Global Forensic Cultures: Making Fact and Justice in the Modern Era, edited by Ian Burney and Christopher Hamlin, 86-111. Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press., 20019.
  4. Mukharji, Projit. “Hylozoic Anticolonialism: Archaic Modernity, Internationalism, and Electromagnetism in British Bengal, 1909-1940.” Osiris, Special Issue: "Presenting Futures Past: Science Fiction and the History of Science" 34, no. 1 (2019): 101-20.
  5. Mukharji, Projit. “Akarnan: The Stethoscope and Making of Modern Ayurveda, Bengal, c. 1894-1952.” Technology & Culture 60, no. 4 (2019): 953-978.
  6. Mukharji, Projit. “Cat and Mouse: Animal Technologies, Trans-Imperial Networks and Public Health from Below, British India, c. 1907-1918.” Social History of Medicine 31, no. 3 (2018): 510-32.
  7. Mukharji, Projit. “The Bengali Pharaoh: Upper-Caste Aryanism, Pan-Egyptianism, and the Contested History of Biometric Nationalism in Twentieth-Century Bengal.” Comparative Studies in Society & History 59, no. 2 (2017): 446-478.
  8. Mukharji, Projit. “Vernacularizing the Body: Informational Egalitarianism, Hindu Divine Design and Race in Physiology School Books, Bengal 1859-1877.” Bulletin of the History of Medicine 91, no. 3 (2017): 554-85.
  9. Mukharji, Projit. “Parachemistries: Colonial Chemopolitics in a Zone of Contes.” History of Science 54, no. 4 (2016): 1-21.
  10. Mukharji, Projit. “From Serosocial to Sanguinary Identities: Caste, Transnational Race Science and the Shifting Metonymies of Blood Group B, India c. 1918-60.” Indian Economic & Social History Review 51, no. 2 (2014): 143-176.

Related Position(s)

Publications

  2. Nelson, Eli. “When Colonization Road Ends….” In Extraction Empire: Sourcing the Scales, Systems, and States of Canada’s Global Resource Empire, edited by Pierre Bélanger. Cambridge: MIT Press, 2018.
  3. “Canoes in Space,” in Shireen Hamza (producer), Ventricles Podcast, Season 1, Ep. 5, 2018: https://ventricles.simplecast.fm/dc580fc6.

Council 4

Irina Podgorny

Irina Podgorny's Website

Current Position

Investigadora Principal, CONICET, Museo de La Plata, UNLP, Argentina

Related Position(s)

Director Historical Archive, Museo de La Plata, Argentina

HSS and Related Activities

  • HSS Committee on Meetings and Programs (CoMP), 2018-
  • President, The History of Earth Sciences Society, 2019-202
  • 0 Editorial Board, Science in Context, History of Humanities, Journal for the History of Knowledge, Earth Sciences History
  • Advisory Board, Shanghai Archaeology Forum, Institute of Archaeology, Chinese Academy of Social Sciences
  • Jury- Mejor Artículo-LASA 2020 (Latin American Studies Association) - Nineteenth Century Section

Publications

  1. Podgorny, Irina. Diccionario histórico de las ciencias de la Tierra en la Argentina. Rosario, Argentina: Prohistoria, 2016.
  2. Podgorny, Irina. “Requiem, oder ( Aus- ) Sterben in historischer und geologischer Zeit. Knöchelverzeichnis KV 62.” Archiv für Mediengeschichte 18 (2018): 129-142.
  3. Podgorny, Irina. “A horse-cloth for Uganda, or how an account by a transhumant veterinary connects histories, animal diseases and continents.” History and Technology 34, no. 1 (2018): 71-78.
  4. Podgorny, Irina. “The elk, the ass, the tapir, their hooves, and the falling sickness: A story of substitution and animal medical substances.” Journal of Global History 13 (2018): 46-68.
  5. Podgorny, Irina. “Manifest Ambiguity: Intermediate Forms, Variation, and Mammal Paleontology in Argentina, 1830-1880.” Studies in History and Philosophy of Science Part C: Studies in History and Philosophy of Biological and Biomedical Sciences 66 (2017): 27-36.
  6. Podgorny, Irina. ““Los Pichiciegos.” Scraps of Information and the Affinities of South American Mammals in the 19th Century.” In Global Scientific Practice in an Age of Revolutions, edited by Patrick Manning and Daniel Rood, 163-178. Pittsburgh: University of Pittsburgh Press, 2016.

Council 7

Matteo Valleriani

Matteo Valleriani's Website

Current Position

Research Group Leader, Max Planck Institute for the History of Science

Related Position(s)

Honorary Prof. Technische Universität Berlin, Prof. for Special Appointments at the Tel Aviv University

HSS and Related Activities

  • My first HSS annual meeting was in 2007 in Arlington. Many further annual meetings followed.
  • I was Advisory Editor of the Journal Isis between 2015 and 2017

Publications

  1. Valleriani, Matteo. Galileo Engineer. Dordrecht: Springer, 2010.
  2. Valleriani, Matteo (ed.), De Sphaera of Johannes de Sacrobosco in the Early Modern Period: The Authors of the Commentaries, Springer Nature, Cham, 2020.
  3. Valleriani, Matteo (ed.), The Structures of Practical Knowledge, Springer, Dordrecht, 2017.
  4. Valleriani, Matteo. “The Emergence of Epistemic Communities in the Sphaera Corpus: Mechanisms of Knowledge Evolution.” Journal of Historical Network Research 3 (2019): 50–91. https://doi.org/10.25517/jhnr.v3i1.63.
  5. Valleriani, Matteo. “Ancient Pneumatics Transformed during the Early Modern Period.” Nuncius 29 (2014): 127–173.
  6. Valleriani, Matteo. Metallurgy, Ballistics and Epistemic Instruments. The «Nova scientia» of Nicolò Tartaglia. Berlin: Edition Open Sources, 2013.

Dora Vargha

Dora Vargha's Website

Current Position

Senior Lecturer

HSS and Related Activities

  • Member, HSS Forum for the History of Health, Medicine, and the Life Sciences, 2019-present
  • Co-Editor, Social History of Medicine journal (Oxford University Press) 2017-present
  • Member, WHO Collaborating Centre for Cultures and Environments of Health, University of Exeter

Publications

  1. Vargha, Dora. Polio across the Iron Curtain: Hungary’s Cold War with an Epidemic. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2018.
  2. Vargha, Dora. “The Socialist World in Global Polio Eradication.” Revue d-Études Comparatives Est-Ouest 49, no. 1 (2018).
  3. Vargha, Dora. “Socialist Utopia in Practice: Everyday Life and Medical Authority in a Hungarian Polio Hospital.” Social History of Medicine 31, no. 2 (2018).
  4. Vargha, Dora. “Grey-market Medicines: diphtheria antitoxin and the decay of biomedical infrastructure.” The Lancet 389 (April 2017).
  5. Vargha, Dora. “Between East and West: Polio Vaccination Across the Iron Curtain in Cold War Hungary.” Bulletin of the History of Medicine 88, no. 2 (2014).
  6. Vargha, Dora. “Beyond Liberal Internationalism.” Journal of Contemporary European History 25, no. 2 (2016).
  7. Vargha, Dora. “Polio and Disability in Hungary.” In Oxford Handbook of Disability History, edited by Catherine Kudlick, Kim Nielsen, and Michael Rembis. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2018.
  8. Vargha, Dora. “Vaccination and the communist state: polio in Eastern Europe.” In The Politics of Vaccination: A Global History, edited by Stuart Blume, Peter Greenough and Christine Holmberg. Manchester: University of Manchester Press, 2017.
  9. Vargha, Dora. “The Medicalization of Sin. The Body of the Prostitute in 19th Century Hungarian Medical Discourse.” Budapest Quarterly [Budapesti Negyed] , no. 47-48 (2005).

Christine von Oertzen's Website

Current Position

Principal Investigator, Max Planck Institute for the History of Science, Berlin

Related Position(s)

Professor, Media Studies Department, Humboldt University, Berlin

HSS and Related Activities

  • Editorial Board, Isis
  • HSS Program Co-Chair 2019 (Utrecht Meeting)

Publications

  1. von Oertzen, Christine. Working With Paper: Gendered Practices in the History of Knowledge. Pittsburgh: University of Pittsburgh Press, 2019.
  2. von Oertzen, Christine. “Keeping Prussia's House in Order: Census Cards, Housewifery, and the State's Data Compilation.” In Working With Paper: Gendered Practices in the History of Knowledge, edited by Carla Bittel, Elaine Leong, Christine von Oertzen, 108-123. Pittsburgh: University of Pittsburgh Press, 2019.
  3. von Oertzen, Christine. “Datafication and Spatial Visualization in Nineteenth-Century Census Statistics.” Historical Studies in the Natural Sciences 48, no. 5 (2018): 568-580. https://doi.org/10.1525/hsns.2018.48.5.568.
  4. Data Histories, ed. Elena Aronova, Christine von Oertzen, David Sepkoski. Osiris 32, 2017
  5. von Oertzen, Christine. Science, Gender, and Internationalism: Women's Academic Networks, 1917–1955. New York: MacMillan, 2014.

Nominating Committee 1

Charlotte Bigg

Charlotte Bigg's Website

Current Position

Permanent Research Fellow

HSS and Related Activities

  • I have attended several HSS meetings since 2001

Publications

  1. C. Bigg, K. Vanhoutte, eds. "Spectacular Astronomy," special issue of Early Popular Visual Culture 15, no. 2, 2017.
  2. A. Bergeron, C. Bigg, eds. "The Spatial Inscription of Science," special issue of History of Science (forthcoming 2020).
  3. Bigg, Charlotte. The Heavens on Earth: Observatories and Astronomy in the Nineteenth Century. Durham, NC: Duke University Press, 2010.
  4. Bigg, Charlotte. “Diagrams.” In Companion to the History of Science, edited by B. Lightman, 557-571. Wiley-Blackwell, 2016.
  5. Bigg, Charlotte. “Of Blurs, Maps and Portraits: Photography and the Moon.” In Selene’s Two Faces: From 17th Century Drawings to Spacecraft Imaging, edited by C. Pérez-González. Brill, 2018.
  6. Bigg, Charlotte. “Travelling Scientist, Circulating Images and the Making of the Modern Scientific Journal: Norman Lockyer’s Visual Communication of Astrophysics in Nature.” Nuncius 30, no. 3 (2015): 675-698.
  7. Bigg, Charlotte. “(avec Andrée Bergeron) “Built in Thoughts Rather Than Stone." The Palais de la Découverte and the 1937 Exhibition in Paris.” In Scientific Heritage at World Exhibitions and beyond.The Long 20th Century, edited by M. Beretta, E. Canadelli & L. Ronzon. Smithsonian institution Press, 2019.
  8. Bigg, Charlotte. “Portrait of the Scientist as a Chercheur. The Making of a New Figure in Early Twentieth Century Media.” In Gesichter der Wissenschaft, Repräsentanz und Performanz von Gelehrten in Porträts, edited by C. Vogel & S. Nöckel, 147-160. Wallstein, 2019.
  9. Bigg, Charlotte. “Le siècle de l’atome en images.” In Histoire des sciences et des savoirs, vol. 3: Le Siècle des technosciences, edited by C. Bonneuil & D. Pestre, 167-185. Seuil, 2015.
  10. Bigg, Charlotte. “The View from Here, There and Nowhere? Situating the Observer in the Planetarium and in the Solar System.” Early Popular Visual Culture 15, no. 2 (2017): p. 209-231.
Nominating Committee 2

Maria Pia Donato

Maria Pia Donato's Website

Current Position

Research Professor, CNRS/Institut d'Histoire Moderne et Contemporaine, Paris, France

Related Position(s)

Corresponding member, Académie Internationale d'Histoire des Sciences

Publications

  1. Donato, Maria Pia. Sudden Death. Medicine and Religion in Eighteenth-Century Rome. Ashgate, 2014.
  2. Donato, Maria Pia. “Galen in an Age of Change (1650–1820).” In Brill’s Companion to the Reception of Galen, edited by Petros Bouras-Valliantos and Barbara Zipser, 487-507. Brill, 2019.
  3. Donato, Maria Pia. “Medicine and the Inquisition in the Early Modern World. Introduction.” Early Science and Medicine 23, no. 1-2 (2018): 1-13.
  4. Donato, Maria Pia. “The Afterlife of the Non-naturals in Early 18th-Century Hippocratism: from a Healthy Individual to a Healthy Population.” In Conserving Health in Early Modern Culture. Bodies and Environments in Italy and England,, edited by Sandra Cavallo and Tessa Storey, 158-180. Manchester University Press, 2017.
  5. Donato, Maria Pia. “Faire corps : les académies dans l’ancien régime des sciences (XVIIe-XVIIIe siècles).” In Histoire des sciences et des savoirs, edited by Dominique Pestre, 81-109. Seuil, 2015.
  6. Donato, Maria Pia. “Science on the Fringe of the Empire. The Academy of the Linceans in the Early Nineteenth Century.” Nuncius. Journal for the Material and Visual History of Science 27 (2012): 210-240.
  7. Donato, Maria Pia. “Il normale, il patologico e la sezione cadaverica in età moderna.” Quaderni Storici , no. 136 (2011): 75-98.
  8. Donato, Maria Pia. “Late Seventeenth-Century ‘Scientific’ Academies in Rome and the Cimento’s Disputed Legacy.” In The Accademia del Cimento and its European Context, edited by Marco Beretta, Antonio Clericuzio and Lawrence M. Principe, 151-164. Science History Publications, 2009.
  9. Donato, Maria Pia. “Les doutes de l’Inquisiteur. Philosophie naturelle, censure et théologie à l’époque moderne.” Annales E.S.S. 64 (2009): 15-43.
  10. Donato, Maria Pia. “Introduction.” In Conflicting Duties. Science, Medicine and Religion in Rome, 1550-1750, edited by Maria Pia Donato and Jill Kraye, 1-8. The Warburg Institute, 2009.

Nominee for Secretary

Secretary Nominee

  • Luis Campos
Secretary 1

Luis Campos

Luis Campos's Website

Current Position

Associate Professor and Regents' Lecturer, History Department, University of New Mexico

HSS and Related Activities

  • HSS Secretary, 2017-present
  • HSS Nominating Committee, 2014-2015
  • HSS Forum for the History of Science in America (FHSA), steering committee, 2012-2014
  • Member of the Editorial Board, Journal of the History of Biology
  • I have attended every HSS meeting since 2000 apart from one.

Publications

  1. Campos, Luis. Radium and the Secret of Life. University of Chicago Press, 2015.
  2. Campos, Luis. “Life as It Could Be.” In Social and Conceptual Issues in Astrobiology, edited by Kelly Smith and Carlos Mariscal, 101-114. Oxford University Press, 2020.
  3. Campos, Luis. “Other Genetic Alphabets.” Journal of Design and Science (December 2018).
  4. Campos, Luis. “Neanderthals in Space: George Church’s Modest Steps Toward Possible Futures.” In Dreamers, Visionaries and Revolutionaries in the Life Sciences, edited by Oren Harman and Michael Dietrich, 143-160. University of Chicago Press, 2018.
  5. Campos, Luis. “Dialectics Denied: Muller, Lysenkoism, and the Fate of Chromosomal Mutation.” In The Lysenko Controversy as a Global Phenomenon: Genetics and Agriculture in the Soviet Union and Beyond, edited by William de Jong-Lambert, and Nikolai Krementsov. Palgrave-Macmillan, 2017.
  6. Campos, Luis. “Outsiders and In-Laws: Drew Endy and the Case of Synthetic Biology.” In Outsider Scientists: Routes to Innovation in Biology, edited by Oren Harman and Michael Dietrich, 331-348. University of Chicago Press, 2013.
  7. Campos, Luis. “The BioBrick™ Road.” Biosocieties 7, no. 2 (June 2012): 115-139.
  8. Campos, Luis. Making Mutations: Objects, Practices, Contexts. Berlin: Max Planck Institute for the History of Science, 2010.
  9. Campos, Luis. “The Birth of Living Radium.” Representations 97 (2006): 1-29.

Publications

  1. Kay, Gwen. “Home Economics Students, Past, Present, and Future.” In Service as Mandate: Land-Grant Universities and the Making of the Modern World, edited by Alan Marcus. University of Alabama, 2015.
  2. Kay, Gwen. “Changing Names, Keeping Identity.” In Remaking Home Economics, edited by Sharon Y. Nickols and Gwen Kay. University of Georgia Press, 2015.
  3. Kay, Gwen. “‘If It Did Not Exist, It Would Have to Be Invented:’ Home Economics in Transition at Iowa’s Regents Institutions.” In Annals of Iowa, , 132-160. 2011.
  4. Kay, Gwen. Dying to Be Beautiful: The Fight for Safe Cosmetics. Ohio State University Press, 2005.
